Any C expert here btw? I'm trying to figure this code out. I can't for the life of me figure out how score_array is being put together: <http://hastebin.com/zugikuleno.c> See #688 for update_score but I have no idea how it is score_array has a value.
I understand the whole maximini and alpha beta pruning, but that scoring thing is mind boggling
I just can't find the piece of code that changes the score_array.

I can only see it being setup, I cannot see how it contains the values it should. It should contain the values of the statistics of the players based on the amount of winning moves it can achieve. Ya even that I barely understand.
<@U061HDV96>: it seems to me that at #759 `push_state` it loops through the whole board and updates the scores
wait no, isn't the update of the scores happening in the function that you mentioned? Everything starts from 1 and at the end of each turn it updates according to the differences
In push_state it just copies from the old to the new
But where does the initial value get set?
update_score sets score
not score_array
the score_array is initialized to all 1 at #208
score_array is modified through the `current_score_array` pointer at #701 and #702
it's a pointer to a pointer
yeah and the `this_difference` and `other_difference` are used to update the actual scores instead of looping over `score_array` because of efficiency as mentioned at #74
Can you explain to me how it calculates the scores?
And what is the difference between scores_array and scores?

so as far as I understand each turn on the board is associated with two "turn" scores, one for player0 and one for player1. This turn score can have either 1 or 0 and it is initialized to 1. So for player0 at turn 3 the turn score would be score_array[0][2] which could be either 1 or 0 and for player1 it would be score_array[1][2] which again could be either 1 or 0.

Now the total score of each player is the sum of all his scores together
the problem is that I am not 100% if it refers to a turn score or not, the key to it is the `win_index` variable for sure
I am stupid I just realized that this is a different type of board game
So I still believe that the `win_index` has to do with turns
on each turn either the current player occupied a piece or not, if he did he gets 1 if not 0
It's connect four btw :stuck_out_tongue:
Also
<@U09T8SFG8>: when is it 1 and when is it 0 then?
I am honestly not sure about that. But I believe that 1 means that the player has occupied a piece and 0 means he did not
Occupied a piece?
Wouldn't he always occupy a piece?
wait no, 1 means the position on the board is occupied by a piece
Why would score_array[0][2] give the occupancy of the board?
it gives for the 3rd turn if player0 occupied a position on the board or not
You mean put in a piece?
Why wouldn't he put in a piece?
occupied I believe means locking a piece
Locking a piece?
Doesn't it always lock in a piece?
You put it in, why would it try to save failed attempts?
look at this gif on the last row and column <https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/a/ad/Connect_Four.gif>
yellow got occupied by red
bottom right
What exactly do you mean with 'occupied'?
Player 0 puts in a piece
And then player 1 another one on top of that?
yeah
Why would that give a score point?
but now that I think about it I don#t think that the stats depend on that
ohhhhhhh shit ok he uses 1 and 0 in two different ways
for the `board` `board[3][2] == 1` means that at position [3][2] player1 has a piece there
Yes that I know
I don't get the score stuff :stuck_out_tongue:
ok I think I get it
now score_array[0][x] keeps track of how many pieces player0 needs to win
Yup that's what I thought
But how does it calculate that?
so if `score_array[0][2] == 3` that means that somewhere on the board (the x acts like a stack) player0 has 3 pieces connected together and only needs a 4th one
`score_array[0][5] == 2` means that somewhere else on the board player0 has 2 connected ones
is the 2 then the number turn?
and 5
I don't think so, or not exactly at least

<@U0JBR7LUV>: it depends on the naming conventions of the company. You can read up on Oracle's conventions <http://www.oracle.com/technetwork/java/codeconventions-135099.html> and Google's <https://google.github.io/styleguide/javaguide.html>
I personally go for whatever is closer to the natural language
<@U0JBR7LUV>: then change it to `isReplyable` or `isAbleToReply` or something
so `canReply` and `isAMonkey`

So this is the score thing: ``` stats[2][z] = an array containing statistics of each player.  Statistics
                  for player 0 are contained in stats[0], while statistics
                  for player 1 are contained in stats[1].  stats[a][b] will
                  contain 0 if the n-in-a-row area b is no longer a
                  winning possibility for player a.  Otherwise it will
                  contain 2^p, where p is the number of pieces player a has
                  in this area.```
What a horrible explanation

it's probably like chess

how close you are to winning

                  contain 0 if the n-in-a-row area b is no longer a
                  winning possibility for player a.```

Oh wait
So map[x][y] contains a list of values and each value represents how that field can be used to win.
And I think stats[player][z] means
Let's say the number 20 means that vertical winning is possible
And that number will be used in n fields (n = 4, connect 4)
Then stats[player][20] will return the amount of pieces the player has out of n (4) or 0 if the area is also occupied by the other player making it impossible to win using those
